title: Watching Guys Fire Rockets
segmentation: I'm honored to invite Jonathan Morgan up to the stage who comes from Russia.
He is giving us about crisis net and I was instructed on Twitter to clap hardest for him.
So please help me on joining Jonathan Morgan.
Thanks Jake, thanks everybody for having us.
So like Dick mentioned, I'm Jonathan Morgan.
I'm a software architect and product developer and I work with an organization called Ushite.
And so the key is a technology company.
We're based out of Kenya and we make everything.
So we make technology products.
We do programming, but the essence of what we do is essentially to make humanitarian work better.

So if like humanitarians or James Bond and they are kind of down in the trenches, making everything happen were like you were like the friendly geek who makes this stuff so James Bond can do his job better.
And so this thing that I've learned working with a lot of humanitarian data is that.
It sucks like humanitarian data is a disaster.
It's kind of collected in random little corners of the Internet.
Maybe a little cadre of volunteers has put together a spreadsheet that has some roughly structured data that they put in Google Drive, but nobody can remember how to access it.

Or maybe they're an NGO that's collected some data and it's on a server somewhere that nobody remembers how to get to because the technical guy left the project and maybe it's Microsoft Access and we definitely don't understand.
Or there may be an NGO who releases the data, but like a week late and it's aggregating.
It's kind of useful, but we're not really sure but.
Ultimately, what we want to do is take that information and layer on top of it.
Something real time, like maybe Twitter hashtags or Facebook information or whatever.
And this process is constant over and over and over again.
We're going through these steps and so we decided to make a platform called Crisis Net that would collect all of this different information together.
So the point is, is that we're looking for this kind of data?
That's what, where when data this event data that lets us look into and really see the shape of a crisis?
A disaster or conflict as it unfolds?
So in this context, social media is like the Holy Grail because this is like people that live in places and they talk about what's happening around them and they.
This is inherently time based information, right?
Like it's inherently timely when you share data on social.
That works, but it's a disaster.
It's like it's really messy.
There's 10s of millions of Facebook pages, and millions and millions of YouTube videos that get posted all the time and trying to find.
The information that you're looking for is like finding a really small needle in a really, really big haystack.
So what we decided was that we need to curate this.
Information somehow we need to find people who already know what to look for, and so this is a guy called Eliot Higgins.
He's called Brown Moses on the Internet.
He just released the website called Bellingcat and this guy does open data investigations.

So what he does is he went through all of these Facebook pages in YouTube channels manually and he discovered that militant groups operating in Syria Self promote on social networks just like everybody else, right?
So like they post videos of themselves holding rockets and firing into the distance to look like badasses or whatever.
And the point being is that there's actually interesting operational information captured in these social media posts, so his big is like big breakthrough.
Was that he was able to show that there were chemical weapons attacks in Syria just by looking at social media content before international intelligence agencies, right?
So the data is out there.
But the problem is.
Is that is that Elliot's doing all of this by himself, right?
Like reading 10,000 Facebook posts and watching 1000 YouTube videos everyday is not particularly scalable even for somebody who really likes spending all of their time on the computer.

So I met Elliot and I told him that we were working on this data platform called Crisis Net and we might just be able to take all this data that he was aggregating personally and put it into a single platform to make it easier to use.
So crisis now.
So.
So we took Elliot's data from Facebook, YouTube and Twitter and whatever we put it through.
Our platform and we started pulling out the actionable information.
So like a lot of systems, we have a processing pipeline.
We do entity extraction and plot the names of people, places and things.
We geolocate things.
We do machine translation and so on and so on to get back.

After this, what where when data that we need and what we discovered was that that information coming out of Syria is a desert like it's it's appalling, but when you're doing this kind of work you don't make tragedy porn, right?
Like you need to get some kind of knowledge out of the data that your work.
And so we took the information and we put it on a map and.
And what's interesting here is that the little this heat map that we built this is.
This is an accurate representation of the intensity of the conflict in Syria, just from the Facebook data that we collected and put through our pipeline.
And if you can see here it compared to another map, this is a map of the BBC generated.

They used information collected by NGOs operating on the ground, so this is information collected over a number of weeks from people that were on the Jordanian Syria border, and there's our map on the right, and they're not identical, but they're pretty close, and so this data that I collected from Elliot sources on my couch in Austin turns out to be an accurate representation of what's happening on the ground in Syria, just from Facebook.
So we went a little further.
We went barrel bomb hunting and barrel bombs or IED's.
They are improvised explosive devices that are used in Syria.
They usually disseminate chemical weapons so they're nasty stuff.
It's important to know for human rights reasons where they fall.

And so my colleague at Crisis net, the project co-founder Chris Albon dug into the information and he was able to locate by just using keywords in the names of towns mentioned in Syria where these bombs were falling.
Which is the best thing you've ever heard in your life?
This is fantastic.
We're changing the world, but great.
What can we all do?
So this is a conference full of data scientists.
You guys are all bro.
And people and we could definitely use your help.
This is an open source platform.
If you're looking for a project to do in your spare time, you can apply all of your genius to saving the world.
Or if you'd like to get paid for it, we're hiring right now for people that do data visualization an for data scientists.
So if you're interested in having the best job that you'll ever have, feel free to come find me.
I am very excited to drink beer with you for the rest of the evening.
And.
That's the end.
Thanks very much.
